message.content: This question requires some knowledge about genetics and inheritance. Zebras have a characteristic coat pattern with black and white stripes. If a zebra has more black than white on its body, it means it has more genes for black stripes. When this zebra has a calf, the calf has a higher probability of inheriting the black stripe genes. Therefore, the calf will be mostly black. Option (A) is incorrect because dark brown is not a common color for zebras. Option (B) is incorrect because the calf will not inherit the genes for mostly white. Option (C) is incorrect because there is no reason for the calf to be bald.

This question is about the inheritance of traits in zebras. Zebras have a pattern of black and white stripes on their bodies, and this pattern is determined by their genes. The genes for stripe color and pattern are passed down from parent to offspring. If a zebra has more black than white on its body, it means that it has more genes for black stripes. When this zebra has a calf, the calf will inherit its parent's genes. Therefore, the calf will also have more black than white on its body, leading to the answer choice (D) that it will be mostly black. Option (A) is incorrect because there is no information suggesting that the calf will be dark brown. Option (B) is incorrect because there is no information suggesting that the calf will be mostly white. Option (C) is incorrect because there is no information suggesting that the calf will be bald.
